channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Modern Perl developers needed to drive medical diagnosis into the future
item.description: A Cambridge-based provider of a revolutionary diagnostic tool for clinicians is looking for Modern Perl developers who are passionate about using their tech skills to help further the field of medicine. Youâ€™ll be building the tools that scientists are using to cure disease.

item.title: Love independent music? Hipster not a dirty word to you? Drive forward independent music with Perl.
item.description: Youâ€™ll help build out a Modern Perl platform ahead of international expansion. The team uses Catalyst, TT, Moose with Plack and mod_perl, as well as the sensible testing tools youâ€™d expect. The team has a multi-technology approach, also using Node for some services, Elastic Search, nginx, and Postgres. Deployment is managed using Ansible.

item.title: Save the world then go get piste -- Mid-level Perl developer and ski-master in Sevenoaks, Kent
item.description: Youâ€™ll be working with a Modern Perl stack deployed to AWS on Mojolicious with a strong focus on testing and continuous integration, and the infinite wisdom of one of CPANâ€™s most prolific (and nicest) contributors at hand. The company helps charities fundraise online and works in online payments; youâ€™ll literally be saving the world a little bit with every line of code you commit.

item.title: Could you service an audience of 10 Million+?
item.description: Sometimes when young companies reach a certain level of success, complacency sets in. The culture (subtly) shifts from entrepreneurial to bureaucratic. Thatâ€™s not this client. Instead of toasting themselves, they keep rolling.

item.title: Sick of jobs lacking purpose? This Perl job literally cures the worldâ€™s ills
item.description: Based out of the leafy city of Cambridge â€“ a home for everyone from Darwin to Hawking â€“ youâ€™ll be working for a company specialising in genomics, whose platform aids clinicians in investigating the human genome, identifying diseases and working to beat them.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland

item.title: European PerlCon 2019
item.description: August 7-9, 2019 Riga, Latvia

item.title: North American Perl Conference 2019
item.description: June 2019 Pittsburgh

item.title: French Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: June 19-22, 2019 Strasbourg, France

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Why I love Perl 6
item.description: An unsurprisingly excellent show of the power of Perl 6 with all the right words to trigger any hard-core Perl hater. See Reddit thread for even more fun.

item.title: A unique square and rank â€“ Perl weekly challenge, week 9
item.description: Yozen joined the team recently and shared his solution with the blog. This is the first time he ever blogged which makes it even more special.

item.title: A unique square and rank â€“ Perl weekly challenge, week 9
item.description: Francis used Bags of #Perl6 to solve square number challenge. For the ranking challenge, he went all out with the black magic of #Perl6.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 009
item.description: Adam is one of the consistent blogger about weekly challenge. He again came up with clean solution with lots of explanation.

item.title: Solving the Sparkpost Challenge
item.description: Joelle is one the few participants who took on the API challenge seriously. Although it is optional, she never misses it. Here again she not only solved the challenge but also dedicated an entire blog talking about her journey.

item.title: Squared Ranking with Perl 6
item.description: Arne with his unique style of writing amazes me every week. I just love reading his blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 9: Square Numbers and Functional Programming in Perl
item.description: Laurent wrote another blog talking about the use Functional Programming to solve the challenge. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 9: Squares and Rankings
item.description: As always the case with Laurent, you are served with plenty of choices. Each blog of him can easily be turned into chapter in book. Who knows one day, with his permission, I might do that.

item.title: Finding First Square with Five Distinct Digits, Plus
item.description: For ranking challenge, Dave tried different approach. He never shy away from #Perl magical opertaor, e.g. ++$x**2

item.title: Ranking in Perl
item.description: Dave's solves the ranking challenge with plenty of documentation, It is such a fun reading his code.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 009
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 010
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Creating a Twitter List of CPAN Authors
item.description: Olaf introduces us to t, a little Twitter command line tool. He also creates a Twitter list of all the CPAN authors who have shared their ID via MetaCPAN. I found quite a few funny and interesting posts.

item.title: Docker and Dancer
item.description: Dave ongoing blog series about his project "Moving Into the Cloud". This time with the correct link. Hopefully.

item.title: berrybrew 1.23 released!
item.description: The perlbrew for Windows Strawberry Perl!

item.title: Managing Your Travis CI Config Files with App::CISetup
item.description: I admit I don't understand yet when would I want to automate the creation and maintenance of my Travis-CI configuration file, but if at one point I need it, I know where to turn. Besides I learned about Travis-CI being bought by Idera, a company I've never heard of.

item.title: Perl Is Still The Goddess For Text Manipulation
item.description: Simple one-liners are still sexy even if you use python for everything else.

item.title: TIL - Object Method: Named Arguments Unpacking
ElasticSearch CLI Tools - Part 1
The Perl Conference Late May Newsletter
Get premium wall, floor and window custom decals at StickerYou.com
item.description: StickerYou doesn't only allow you to make custom stickers for your business. Brand your office, store or event with high-quality, customdecals. Make a huge impact and let the world know that your business is a force to be reckoned with. StickerYou.com allows you to order any size, shape and quantity. What are you waiting for? Get your office or store makeover started today at StickerYou.com! Use code PERL10 at checkout for an exclusive Perl Weekly discount.

item.title: #409 - Fun with Python (programmers)
item.description:
Hi there

I have been writing Python for several years now, primarily because that's what my clients use. I attend Python events. I even help organizing some of them. Yet I still don't see myself as part of any Python tribe. It seems they have a requirement of hating Perl, which is, well, very strange.

However, I can have great fun with Python programmers. Especially seeing how some of them can be triggered by a post about Perl 6. Thanks to Damian who provided the excellent blog post.

And as for the rest of you, enjoy your week!
